topic_metadata.title: How can I exclude page number for Heading 1 in outline list?

posts.name: Mark Hilton
posts.cooked:
Another newbie question (from a retired, humanities person!). I have set up a template which does most of what I want, but I do wish to modify it in a couple of ways relating to the outline.

The first is this one: My 4 levels of headings are working as I want with only Headings 1 and 2 appearing in the outline. But what I would like in the outline is for only the text of Heading 1 to be shown, without the dots and the page number.

This is my current code for headings and outline:

#show heading.where(
  level: 1
): it => block(sticky: true, width: 100%)[
  #set align(center)
  #set text(24pt, weight: "regular")
  #smallcaps(it.body)
]

#show heading.where(level: 2): set text(20pt, weight: "semibold")

#show heading.where(level: 3): set text(16pt, weight: "semibold")

#show heading.where(level: 4): set text(14pt, weight: "semibold")

#outline(
  depth: 2,
  title: ([Contents]),
  target: heading.where(outlined: true),
  indent: 18pt,
)

#show outline.entry.where(
  level: 1
): it => {
  v(1em, weak: true)
  strong(it)
}
#show outline.entry.where(
  level: 2
): it => {
  v(0.3em, weak: true)
  strong(it)
}

which gives me:

SCR-20250422-kgsq1342×196 33.7 KB

when what I’d really like is:

SCR-20250422-kiwu900×184 42 KB

How can I achieve this? (The latter I mocked up in a word processor hence the difference in font appearance etc. which can be ignored).


Mark
posts.raw:
Another newbie question (from a retired, humanities  person!). I have set up a template which does most of what I want, but I do wish to modify it in a couple of ways relating to the outline.

The first is this one: My 4 levels of headings are working as I want with only Headings 1 and 2 appearing in the outline. But what I would like in the outline is for only the text of Heading 1 to be shown, without the dots and the page number.

This is my current code for headings and outline:

``` typ
#show heading.where(
  level: 1
): it => block(sticky: true, width: 100%)[
  #set align(center)
  #set text(24pt, weight: "regular")
  #smallcaps(it.body)
]

#show heading.where(level: 2): set text(20pt, weight: "semibold")

#show heading.where(level: 3): set text(16pt, weight: "semibold")

#show heading.where(level: 4): set text(14pt, weight: "semibold")

#outline(
  depth: 2,
  title: ([Contents]),
  target: heading.where(outlined: true),
  indent: 18pt,
)

#show outline.entry.where(
  level: 1
): it => {
  v(1em, weak: true)
  strong(it)
}
#show outline.entry.where(
  level: 2
): it => {
  v(0.3em, weak: true)
  strong(it)
}

```

which gives me:

![SCR-20250422-kgsq|690x100](upload://z1VimPQM5RZCIeeFxuYFsF0TCen.png)

when what I'd really like is:

![SCR-20250422-kiwu|690x141](upload://oKng7PbizIp9U7l0AqdOfwXho9.png)

How can I achieve this? (The latter I mocked up in a word processor hence the difference in font appearance etc. which can be ignored).

:slight_smile: 
 Mark

posts.name: Vincent Martel
posts.cooked:
Hi @Mark_Hilton,

If you have a look at Outline Function – Typst Documentation, you will find the hint on how to do it.

An adapted version of the example is:

#show outline.entry.where(level: 1): it => link(
  it.element.location(),
  // Keep just the body, dropping
  // the fill and the page.
  it.indented(it.prefix(), it.body()),
)

#outline()

= About ACME Corp.
== History

Which leads to the desired output:

image1034×236 82.1 KB
posts.raw:
Hi @Mark_Hilton,

If you have a look at https://typst.app/docs/reference/model/outline/#building-an-entry, you will find the hint on how to do it. 

An adapted version of the example is:

```typ
#show outline.entry.where(level: 1): it => link(
  it.element.location(),
  // Keep just the body, dropping
  // the fill and the page.
  it.indented(it.prefix(), it.body()),
)

#outline()

= About ACME Corp.
== History
```

Which leads to the desired output:
![image|690x157](upload://iNHwD8wyGXVbwyRwTPOAuhKLLEg.png)

posts.name: Mark Hilton
posts.cooked:
Hi @vmartel08, thank you very much for your input. This solves the issue.

To tell you the truth, the problem for someone like me, with a background in the humanities and no background in coding, is that it is sometimes difficult to work out how to achieve what one wants because the examples often seem somewhat impenetrable.


Mark

:slight_smile:

posts.cooked:
@Mark_Hilton, please try and format your code blocks appropriately like mentioned in How to post in the Questions category :

How to post in the Questions category

If your question pertains to a bit of Typst markup you have problems with, put it in the question body! You can syntax-highlight Typst code by wrapping it in ` ```typ … ````. It will then look like this:

#set font(size: 12pt)

Hello from *Typst* at $ pi.var + 1 $ o'clock!

If you need to highlight a code or math mode snippet instead, the language tags typc and typm do that, respectively.

It would be great if you could post the smallest possible code samples that allow people to see what your problem is.
posts.raw:
@Mark_Hilton, please try and format your code blocks appropriately like mentioned in https://forum.typst.app/t/how-to-post-in-the-questions-category/11 :

[quote="reknih, post:1, topic:11"]
If your question pertains to a bit of Typst markup you have problems with, put it in the question body! You can syntax-highlight Typst code by wrapping it in ` ```typ ... ````. It will then look like this:

```typ
#set font(size: 12pt)

Hello from *Typst* at $ pi.var + 1 $ o'clock!
```

If you need to highlight a code or math mode snippet instead, the language tags `typc` and `typm` do that, respectively.

It would be great if you could post the **smallest possible code samples** that allow people to see what your problem is.
[/quote]

posts.name: Vincent Martel
posts.cooked: Hi again Mark, that’s why there is a forum about it . Lots of it comes from reading around and trial and error. Please come back should you have more questions.
posts.raw: Hi again Mark, that’s why there is a forum about it 😊. Lots of it comes from reading around and trial and error. Please come back should you have more questions.

posts.name: Mark Hilton
posts.cooked:
My apologies; I thought I had syntax-highlighted the code correctly, but I must have typed typst rather than typ.

As for “minimum code snippet”, I posted only what I thought would be necessary for others to see; clearly I was mistaken in my estimate, so again I apologise. I have much to learn!


Mark
posts.raw:
My apologies; I thought I had syntax-highlighted the code correctly, but I must have typed `typst` rather than `typ`.

As for "minimum code snippet", I posted only what I thought would be necessary for others to see; clearly I was mistaken in my estimate, so again I apologise. I have much to learn!

:slight_smile: 
 Mark

posts.cooked:
Mark_Hilton:

I thought I had syntax-highlighted the code correctly, but I must have typed typst rather than typ.

typst and typ are identical. You can still edit your message and change that.
posts.raw:
[quote="Mark_Hilton, post:6, topic:3754"]
I thought I had syntax-highlighted the code correctly, but I must have typed `typst` rather than `typ`.
[/quote]

`typst` and `typ` are identical. You can still edit your message and change that.

posts.name: Mark Hilton
posts.cooked:
Thanks, sorted. Turned out I had typed (typst) with parentheses!

<dohh!!>


Mark
posts.raw:
Thanks, sorted. Turned out I had typed `(typst)` with parentheses!

<dohh!!>

:slight_smile: 
 Mark
